I am a UX/UI designer with front-end development experience. I previously worked as a Full Stack developer, although I was always more drawn to the front-end, especially UX/UI design. That's why I decided to specialize, and now I have several years of experience creating intuitive and attractive user experiences.

The naming of my professional brand is Toan. This choice is not arbitrary, but is based on a personal and emotional bond that directly reinforces my brand's philosophy: trust and accompaniment throughout the process. Toan is not a random invention, but a word with a deep and personal emotional charge. Its origin dates back to my childhood, when I had difficulty pronouncing the letter 'J' and referred to myself as "Toan" instead of "Joan". This small peculiarity became an affectionate nickname used by my closest loved ones, a symbol of unconditional support and acceptance.

Years later, this name acquired a new dimension when my partner started using "Toan" affectionately, without knowing the story from when I was a child. This coincidence confirmed its meaning for me: the name now symbolizes a path of constant support, trust, and fidelity.
In the professional context, Toan becomes the voice of my brand and the pillar of my value proposition:

When Someone needs to comply with digital accessibility in the digitalization process, Toan promises that the client will not have to face the legal and technical complexity alone, but will be guided by a close relationship and mutual support.
This orthographic singularity and its strong sonority help the brand stand out visually and be easily remembered in an environment often saturated with generic or overly formal names.

Toan is, therefore, more than a name; it is a declaration of trust, a commitment that profitable Accessibility will be delivered with the same care and support found in the most significant personal relationships.

My difference is my hybrid profile (UX/UI, front-end developer, and specialized digital accessibility profile) and my 360° product vision. When a client hires me, they are not just buying a graphic deliverable (the prototype), but the guarantee of an efficient end-to-end process (the solution). The added value I deliver is twofold:
My designs inherently include Frontend logic, as well as compliance with accessibility criteria, semantic naming, wai-aria tags, and QA checking from the design phase.

This integration drastically reduces iterations and errors between design and development teams, which translates into quantifiable savings in the total public project budget. Accessibility becomes a source of efficiency, not an expense.
